conclusion: Use the Ideal Gas Law to find the temperature at state B.
Explanation of the Ideal Gas Law and its variables.
Given temperature at state C is 300K and states A, B, and C lie on the same curve.
At state B, \( P_B = 2 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \) and \( V_B = 5 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \).
At state C, \( P_C = 5 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \) and \( V_C = 2 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \).
Using the Ideal Gas Law for state C: \( P_C V_C = nRT_C \).
Calculate \( nR \) using state C: \( nR = \frac{1000}{300} = \frac{10}{3} \).
Apply the Ideal Gas Law for state B: \( P_B V_B = nRT_B \).
Calculate \( T_B \) using state B: \( T_B = \frac{1000 \times 3}{10} = 300 \, \text{K} \).
The temperature of the gas in state B is 300K.
